passage_text: As the ritual of Temple worship came to an end, synagogues and synagogue services evolved, with an order of prayer established by the sages. Their idea was that the ritual of the Temple sacrifice would be replaced by formal worship. Such services need not take place in a synagogue; they merely require a quorum ('minyan') of at least ten men over 13 years of age (in Orthodoxy-ten men or women in Progressive Judaism) to gather for morning, afternoon and evening prayers.

The idea of a public place for ritual and worship is as old as humanity, with the remains of ancient altars and temples found throughout the world. The modern synagogue combines in its physical structure and in its prayers and ceremonies, the memory of such places in the history of Judaism. The synagogue is the Jewish place of worship, but is also used as a place to study, and often as a community centre as well. Orthodox Jews often use the Yiddish word shul (pronounced shool) to refer to their synagogue. In the USA, synagogues are often called temples. Traditional Jewish worship requires a minyan (a quorum of ten adult males) to take place. In an Orthodox synagogue the service will be conducted in ancient Hebrew, and the singing will be unaccompanied. Few British synagogues now have a choir, but they are more common in the USA.

It is the center of the Jewish religious community: a place of prayer, study and education, social and charitable work, as well as a social center. In fact, in rabbinical literature, the synagogue is sometimes referred to as the little Temple.. A synagogue is usually also a beit midrash, a house of study. Contrary to popular belief, Jewish education does not end at the age of bar mitzvah.
